{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3146571,"name":"Ryan zheng","username":"Rzheng1232","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rzheng1232/{size}/182897_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-16T12:45:05.157Z","cooked":"

For the arm programming, I’m controlling it using a feedforward loop + feedback loop, but I was wondering what was the difference between simple feedforward and arm feed forward. Also do they have any difference in their implementtion

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-02-16T12:45:05.157Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":702,"reads":272,"readers_count":271,"score":3564.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427026,"topic_slug":"is-simple-feed-forward-enough-for-arm-or-do-i-need-arm-feed-forward","display_username":"Ryan zheng","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55168,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/is-simple-feed-forward-enough-for-arm-or-do-i-need-arm-feed-forward/427026/1","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3146576,"name":"vargoose84","username":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-16T12:50:27.904Z","cooked":"

The effect of gravity is stronger when you are parallel to the ground compared to if you are perpendicular. This is why you want to use arm feed forward.

See the wpilib write-up below.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical arm. The same tuning principles explained below will work also for almost all position-control scenarios under the load of ...

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-02-16T12:50:41.359Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":149.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":427026,"topic_slug":"is-simple-feed-forward-enough-for-arm-or-do-i-need-arm-feed-forward","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/tuning-vertical-arm.html#tuning-a-vertical-arm-position-controller","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":158}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/is-simple-feed-forward-enough-for-arm-or-do-i-need-arm-feed-forward/427026/2","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3146577,"name":"Newton Crosby Jr","username":"NewtonCrosbyJr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/newtoncrosbyjr/{size}/163897_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-16T12:50:30.235Z","cooked":"

SimpleFeedForward and ArmFeedForward are just different representations of the same concept, which is just plain old FeedForward (kF in your pid gains).

Essentially, feedforward is the minimum required energy to convert potential (static) energy to kinetic (moving) energy. In a drivetrain, for example, your feedforward is the least amount of output you’d need to overcome friction with the ground and move at all. In an arm, feedforward would be the exact amount of output you need to hold it in place wherever it’s experiencing the most gravity pulling it down (i.e. at full extension or wherever your arm is feeling the most gravity)

WPIlib is kind enough to name these in a way that makes it easier to organize everything. In your case, Arm feedforward is the way to go because that’s what your control loop is for.

Respectfully: this is kind of backwards. kF in FRC motor controller PID configurations is a very specific sort of feedforward.

It’s not quite true that feedforward is a “minimum output”, either. It is true that you can measure the kS term of the typical feedforward equation as the minimum voltage required to cause motion (and with some setups do a similar test for a combined kS + kG term), but this is not itself the definition of what the feedforward is and thinking about the feedforward with this as your “base-case” is going to cause confusion.

Feedforward is a best-guess at the voltage that will cause the desired motion from what you know of your system dynamics and setpoint, without regard for the current state.
